content.title: Polish Literature in English Translations:19th Century
Pisma Kazimierza Brodzińskiego. T. 3 : Proza. O klasyczności i romantyczności (1818). Literatura polska (1822-1823) - Radom Digital Library
The Art of Losing. Polish Poetry and Translation | Specimen - The Babel Review of Translations

results:
Based on the search results, I found some information about Kazimierz Brodziński's work as a translator, though specific details about a Werther translation in 1822 are not directly mentioned in these results.

Kazimierz Brodziński (8 March 1791 - 10 October 1835) was a Polish poet, translator, literary critic, and theoretician. From 1822, he was a professor of Polish literature and stylistics at the University of Warsaw.

He has translated 8 opera librettos, including Mozart's Don Juan, Rossini's Tancredi and Spontini's Milton. Brodziński's knowledge of the German language, obtained at school, led to his very early interest in German literature. He read S. Gessner's pastorals, the works of Schiller and Goethe.

The search results show that Brodziński was indeed active as a translator and had knowledge of German literature, including Goethe's works. However, the specific information about him translating Goethe's "The Sorrows of Young Werther" into Polish in 1822 as the first Polish translation is not explicitly mentioned in these search results.

He dissociated himself as well from the Pre-Romanticism (later Romanticism), which exaggerated the initial tendencies of "Romantic feeling" into poetry of horror and horror (Lonerism), tearfulness (Wertherism) or gloomy and wild fantasy (Bayronism). This reference to "Wertherism" suggests Brodziński was familiar with the cultural impact of Goethe's Werther, though it doesn't confirm he translated it.

The search results do not provide conclusive evidence about whether Brodziński translated Werther in 1822 or if this was indeed the first Polish translation of the work.
